title: Philadelphia's Franklin Institute tests survival skills with 'Worst-Case Scenario' exhibit
text:
CLOSE Based on a best-selling book, 'Worst-Case Scenario Survival Experience' offers a chance to learn how best to escape everything from epidemics to killer bees Tammy Paolino, @CP_TammyPaolino

If you own a smartphone and get news alerts, you know many mornings can seem dystopian.

The Amazon/California/Notre Dame is burning. Islands are being swallowed by superstorms. Water is toxic, drugs are contaminated, and hackers are after your identity – and your last dollar.

The Franklin Institute in Philadelphia can’t mitigate all the world’s dangers, of course.

But the science museum is doing its part to help us survive some increasing threats – floods, for instance – and some much more “Hollywood blockbuster’’ in nature (killer bees and pythons and pirates, oh my!).

No need to panic. We're just going to learn how to defeat cyber criminals, flee a swarm of killer bees and jump between moving train cars at The Franklin Institute's 'Worst-Case Scenario Survival Experience.' (Photo: Tammy Paolino/Courier-Post)

“Worst-Case Scenario: A Survival Experience,’’ a world-premiere, hands-on experience opened Saturday at the museum and runs through April 19 before setting off on a national tour.

Two installations in the exhibit were designed by Mount Laurel-based design firm Kubik-Maltbie Inc., which works on museum experiences all over the world.

The exhibit draws upon “strategies of survival and elements of escape’’ from the best-selling Quirk guidebook series by Philly natives and Penn grads Joshua Piven and David Borgenicht (Chronicle Books). Celebrating its 20th anniversary, the series has sold more than 10 million copies worldwide.

Do you have what it takes to make it through "The Worst-Case Scenario Survival Experience'? (Photo: Tammy Paolino/Courier-Post)

The exhibit kicks off with a “Worst-Case Scenario’’ Hall of Fame, meant to celebrate everyday heroes such as first responders and wildlife rescue workers.

Inside the main gallery, guests are advised to “Be Prepared. Don’t Panic. Have a Plan’’ in a giant sign beside a wall of orange traffic cones.

From there, visitors can test their survival skills in a series of 13 challenges that make up the “Survivor Gym.’’ Here, you will need to draw upon a mix of practical knowledge, physical strength, a grasp of physics and biology, and common sense.

At one station, you will be asked to answer a series of questions to determine how best to survive an unexpected encounter with a bear, a python, an alligator or swarm of killer bees.

A boy plays in a giant ball pit located in the center of 'Worst-Case Scenario Survival Experience' at the Franklin Institute. (Photo: Courtesy of The Franklin Institute / Darryl Moran)

At others, you can test your ability to hang by your fingertips from a ledge or jump between moving “train cars.’’

Think you won’t ever need to know how to safely leap into a dumpster from a third-floor window? Well, we hope you don’t. But it is certainly not a bad thing to learn the best ways to survive a rip tide or escape if your car goes underwater.

Walk through a neon-blue tunnel of plastic strips and see how germs attach themselves to every household surface, then learn what you can do to survive an epidemic or even a pandemic.

As you navigate the stations, you can read step-by-step instructions and glean expert advice to increase your chances of surviving each threat.

Kids on opening day discover what being upside-down can do to their perceptions. (Photo: Courtesy of The Franklin Institute / Darryl Moran)

At a media preview last week, authors Piven and Borgenicht, founder of Quirk Books, greeted guests from inside a giant vat of plastic balls meant to simulate an avalanche in the center of the exhibit. They talked of growing up with The A Team, Indiana Jones, Rambo and James Bond for company – and inspiration.

“When David approached me about this book, you know I loved the idea, plus like all writers I was desperate for cash so I said that sounds great,’’ recalled Piven. “So we got together and started brainstorming this book and the key to the book is that all the information is real even though it is outlandish. We went out and actually found experts to give us the survival advice on the various scenarios … and it was a little weird, like a kid doing a book report on how to escape quicksand.’’

Want to learn how to jump between moving train cars? A Mount Laurel firm designed this portion of the 'Worst-Case Scenario' experience at the Franklin Institute in Philadelphia. (Photo: Tammy Paolino/Courier-Post)

Like the book series, the aim of the exhibit, according to the Franklin, is to “help develop the fundamental skills that are used in all worst-case scenarios: staying calm, thinking logically, using creativity and being prepared.’’

“From evading an angry lion to surviving a shark attack, this exhibit answers: what were the survivors thinking? And what skills did they employ?’’

If you find yourself faced with landing a pilotless plane in the middle of the exhibit and don’t know what to do, no need to panic. Simply walk up to one of the nearby phone booths and get some help from Burt Reynolds, who narrates the original audiobook.

The exhibit at the Franklin Institute is based upon 'The Worst-Case Scenario Survival Handbook' by Joshua Priven and David Borgenicht (Chronicle Books). (Photo: Tammy Paolino/Courier-Post)

If you enjoy the exhibit, you can escape to the gift shop and pick up a revised 20th anniversary edition of the book, which has additional advice for surviving 21st-century threats, such as superstorms, online bullies and “fake news.’’

It might come in handy if, say, you need to decide if that balloon-clutching clown crawling out of that storm drain plans to murder you.

David Campbell of Riverton is project manager for Kubik-Maltbie Inc. in Mount Laurel, which has worked with the Franklin Institute on previous exhibitions. The company designed the train jumping and animal roulette wheel installations.

Their task was to “bring to life’’ the scenarios illustrated in the handbook as closely as possible.

Worst-case scenario for Kubik-Maltbie? That would be one of their installations not holding up to the beating it will take from months’ of hands-on fun.

“When it comes to exhibits, well children are a force of nature. So durability is kind of a big factor for us, so not just figuring out how we can manipulate the motions of what it’s like to jump between trains but making sure it’s going to work for the number of people who are going to jump on this thing.’’

This wheel, part of the 'Worst-Case Scenarios' experience at the Franklin Institute, was designed by a Mount Laurel firm. It offers tips on escaping attacks by various wild animals. (Photo: Tammy Paolino/Courier-Post)

Campbell said he enjoyed working on the roulette wheel concept and would be bringing his own kids so they could spin the wheel and learn how to escape a charging bull.

So, what is Campbell’s worst-case scenario?

“Creaturewise, I guess a rhino. That’s an intimidating animal. I don‘t think that would end well. I don’t want to be anywhere near a rhino. It’s like a living dinosaur.’’

'Be Prepared. Don't Panic. Have a Plan.' That's the motto of the authors of 'Worst-Case Scenario' handbook. (Photo: Tammy Paolino/Courier-Post)

If you go

The Worst-Case Scenario Survival Experience will be at the Mandell Center of the Franklin Institute through April 19. Tickets are $30, $26 for children during the day (9:30 a.m. to 5:30 p.m. with last entry at 3:30 p.m.) and includes admission to the museum. Evening tickets (Thursdays to Saturdays from 5 to 8 p.m. with last entry at 6:30 p.m.) are $20, $15 for children. Visit https://www.fi.edu/

Wash your hands. Not just Mom's advice, it's also part of 'Worst-Case Scenarios' at the Franklin Institute in Philadelphia. (Photo: Tammy Paolino/Courier-Post)
